utterance.speaker: House DividedOriginally Aired
utterance.content: April 27, 2009

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: You look like superman.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: I’m nervous.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: You’re going to kick ass. I think your mom’s trying to get your attention.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Check it out.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: You’re not deaf.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: I’m proud of you.

utterance.speaker: Referee
utterance.content: 145 pounds. Johnson. Miller.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: Good luck.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: AAAAH!

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: AAAAH! OHHHHHHH!

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: House. House. I know you’re not asleep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That insight would be a lot more impressive if you weren’t just a product of my exhausted brain.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Aren’t you curious about why I’m here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Curious why no French maid’s outfit. No spanky pants.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I’m a hallucination, not a fantasy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s insomnia. Four nights without REM sleep can cause—

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: That might explain why you’re hallucinating. Doesn’t explain why you’re hallucinating Wilson’s dead girlfriend.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Probably just my secret and very unconscious desire to get Wilson into my bedroom.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Or maybe your guilt over Kutner’s suicide reminds you how guilty you felt about me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who cares why you’re here. A decent night’s sleep, you won’t be.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Guess I’ll be around a few more hours.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Need some coffee?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Addictive substances are no substitute for nature’s healing balm. Make this fast. I need to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Deaf 14-year-old started hearing imaginary explosions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exploding head syndrome. Cool. Well, obviously his brain knows how to hear.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Patient went deaf at age four. Complication of meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: So why no cochlear implant?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Usual suspects are insomnia, which he doesn’t have; migraines, which he doesn’t get; and head trauma, which didn’t show up on the CT.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Damn imaginary pen.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mom’s signature’s on everything. Did Dad die?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, doubt it. He was a sperm donor. Medical records couldn’t be cleaner.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So we’re left with temporal lobe seizure.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Wrong.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Someone at the wrestling meet would have noticed a seizure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could have just looked like a bad shot to the leg. Put him in the seizure lab. See if his head blows up all over again.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You’re going to ignore your own subconscious? Gonna be the limp leading the blind.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need a scrip for sleeping pills. My neighbor’s dog’s been keeping me awake and seems strangely invulnerable to poison. Why is the soon-to-be-second-prettiest Dr. Chase here?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’ll take that as a congratulations.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’re discussing a case.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Why did he close that file?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wedding in two weeks? I’d say you were pregnant but I don’t think Chase’s body is mature enough to produce sperm.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It’s a small ceremony. Why wait?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Nighty night.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Drugs with no lecture? He wants you out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Interesting case?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Possible prostate cancer came into the ER.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Pencil cup.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ho! No wonder his prostate’s enlarged. It’s full of pool cues and cigars.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Chase’s best man doesn’t get here till the day of the wedding so I asked Wilson to throw his bachelor party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No retired ministers available to plan it?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Chase doesn’t want some big, raucous party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So she says. Luckily, there are people in this world ready to stand up for what’s right.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, no, no. I don’t want — I don’t want you to—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Listen. There are two things I do well. Bachelor parties rank… towards the top.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I get to help, right?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Starting five hertz. House made it through that entire differential without mocking our patient for not having a cochlear implant.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The patient doesn’t want an implant because he’s comfortable with who he is. It’s admirable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s deaf. It’s not an identity, it’s a disability.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’s also a culture. The deaf have their own schools, their own language. Still no spiking.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Going to 20. Anything I can simulate with a $3.00 pair of earplugs is not a culture. No sign of seizure. Temporal lobe activity is still clean.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Doctors, doctors. He can’t see. One of his eyes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The limp leading the blind.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Is that supposed to mean something?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So exploding head syndrome plus vision loss.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Subclavian steel syndrome. Vascular defect coupled with constant arm movement could siphon blood flow from the brain.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We should do an angio—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Knock yourselves out. How did I know he was gonna go blind? Don’t get cute, Gazoo. You’re in my mind. You’re obviously there.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: C-reactive protein. I noticed in his file it was slightly elevated. I figured the stress of the seizure lab would drive inflammation even higher. Lead to optic neuritis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a lot clearer than “the limp leading the blind.”

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It was just a glimmer. I couldn’t put it into words.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It was a long shot. I don’t even remember the c-reactive protein level.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Obviously you do. You just don’t know it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How high is K2?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I don’t know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Me neither. But I read a book about it years ago. Fierce, sexy Sherpa on the cover, bending over—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cool. An all-access pass to my own brain.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Go play the kid some music.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Another long shot.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re using iodine dye to track the blood flow in your neck and arm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What does it look like I’m doing? Fighting the power.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: You’re an ass. He says he feels the vibrations in his abdomen, but not his hands. What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a new symptom. Neuropathy.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Thought you were gonna get some sleep.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Case got interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Like the zoo. Except you can bang on the glass as much as you want.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How did you know about the neuropathy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good question.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Enough with the riddles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tell me about it.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Think “wrestling record.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Juggling. No, pins. Three pins. Patient was pinned in his last three matches. Leading up to that he was 15 and 0. I figured his balance was off from diminished sensation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be increased ICP from a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That we missed on the head CT?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Cutting weight for wrestling could have led to rhabdomyolysis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He just went up a weight class three months ago.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Foreman’s right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, increased ICP could make sense.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You just said—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was processing.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It also puts a new symptom on the table.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His deafness. What if it was caused by NF2 cancer instead of his childhood meningitis?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So meningitis was a coincidence?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or a byproduct of the cancer suppressing his immune system. MRI his head.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If you’re right about NF2, his deafness may be reversible. I’ll set it up and talk to the patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You two… doing anything?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You know what a broken cowboy is? It was on House’s list of requirements.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I have three theories.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why is House so into this bachelor party thing?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He needs a reason to be into a bachelor party?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He needs a reason to be into anything.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Give me your wallet.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House could be trying to tempt Chase into cheating. Break them up.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You think House is into Cameron?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I think House is into Cameron being into him. Marrying Chase would shatter that fantasy.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If Chase cheats then they shouldn’t be getting married in the first place.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So you’re okay with House getting Chase smashed enough to make a stupid mistake?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Being drunk doesn’t change who you are. It just reveals it.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You think she can do the broken cowboy?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: God, I hope so.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: NF2 is an extremely slow-growing cancer which makes it very treatable. If we’re right, taking out the tumor means there’s a chance you’ll regain your hearing.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: No

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: He said you have to.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What’s wrong.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: He wants you to treat the cancer but leave him deaf.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah, sorry. Doesn’t work like that.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: It will be okay.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: I’d have to change schools. I’d barely see you.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: You won’t see me at all unless you get better.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Imaging shows slightly elevated ICP, but no masses on or around the nerves. It’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Slight bowing in the wall of the fourth ventricle could still indicate a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We brought pictures.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The fact that you sent me on a scouting mission—

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: No skirts.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re not on the guest list. Bachelor parties are an ancient and sacred male rite of passage.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The ventricle bowing is most likely a pre-existing anatomical anomaly, not the indication of a tumor.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No way to know for sure without a brain biopsy. If I get drunk enough, there’s a chance I might make out with one of the strippers. Or become one.

utterance.speaker: House and Amber
utterance.content: Sold.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We can’t just drill into our patient’s brain on a hunch.

utterance.speaker: House and Amber
utterance.content: Oh, God, not her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s the one that got me hooked in with Madoff.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Taub’s right. It’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, by all means, abandon a great diagnostic theory because it’s difficult to prove. Do a biopsy. We need to take a better look at his fourth ventricle.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Or an older look.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: The mom’s never gonna let us touch his brain without some evidence.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Patient broke his nose years ago. Hospital could have done an MRI.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The main reason my third wife and I eloped was to avoid House’s bachelor party. Have you seen Caligula?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My patient’s brain now… versus three years ago. See any difference? Is he telling you to avoid the party?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I took an oath to do no harm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure. Don’t come. If you want your wedding vows to be meaningless.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This should be interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You are going to commit to that one special woman forever. Which is beautiful. But if your commitment the day after the wedding is the same as your commitment the day before, then the wedding meant nothing. So, and I see no logical way around this, if you want your marriage to matter, you have to be a wanton, trolling, muck-covered pig the day before.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You’re evil. Se ya.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The wall of the fourth ventricle changed. It isn’t bowed in the older scan.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Evidence of NF2, right?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’d need to do a brain biopsy to confirm. Uh, I’m not going to the bachelor party. Every time I go to one of your parties, I end up embarrassing myself in some new and unexpected way.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That whole thing with the duck was hardly unexpected.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m not going.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It’s not okay.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Do you know who we need? That stripper you got for Wilson’s bachelor party. You could do body shots right off her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why go back to that well? In the nine years since Wilson’s party, a whole new generation of hot girls have been abused by their stepfathers.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: She loved cats.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What made you remember the stripper loved cats?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Chase has a cat. They’ll bond.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ahem, House? You, uh, entertaining yourself up there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just rehearsing for the revival of Evita. What’d you find?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The biopsy shows nerve inflammation consistent with increased intracranial pressure. Something’s wrong, but it’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: He’s going to go through life deaf.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s okay with that.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: He has no idea what he’s missing. His mom’s a moron. He’s gonna pay for her stupidity for the rest of his life? Are *we* okay with that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why are you closing? Supposed to put in a cochlear implant.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Wasn’t in the paperwork.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Really? Well, someone must have screwed up. I’ll go track it down.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll wait.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a great idea. Let the kid spend more time under anesthesia with his skull cracked open.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll wait.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have been known to lie to serve my own agenda. An implant does absolutely nothing to help me diagnose him.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Let’s get an implant tray in here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Just… Just try to relax.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: What did you do to me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Her son didn’t want the implant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If he still doesn’t want it, after having time to adjust, I’ll take it out. I’ll blind him too if he wants to experience that culture.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Remove it now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kid’s just had brain surgery. He’s not stable.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ms. Miller, I’m not trying to minimize Dr. House’s wrongdoing, but the best thing…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Why is she sitting? She’s not yelling, not threatening, not pacing. Just sitting.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Understand, Dr. House? House. Focus. I need you to say you accept the arrangement.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No problem. You’re not mad.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: I’m mad.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not mad enough. You wanted your son to hear. You just didn’t have the guts to make him get the implant.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Once my son is stable, I want that thing out of his head.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why did you do this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because he is ignorant and he’s being raised by an idiot.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Not good enough. You always have—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My patient is opting into a handicap! It’s an insult to all the other gimps out there.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay. But I’m still putting Foreman in charge of the case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s the arrangement? Okay.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You’re okay with Foreman in charge? Who you calling? Oh… Right. You don’t want to look like a lunatic.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, about that…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You think we did the wrong thing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m not sure. I’m not even sure why we did it.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Well, that argument you made to Cuddy sounded pretty good.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To you, maybe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Huh. I figured by now you’d be at the board in your monocle and jodhpurs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah. You did something stupid. Quick, better mock someone.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why did you do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why did I give a human being the power of hearing? You ask God the same question, he’ll give you the same answer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Patient has a fever now too.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Probably just a post-op complication. Arnold-Chiari?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not without muscle weakness.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Pseudotumor Cerebri?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We checked his eyes before the surgery. No papilledema.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Candy. I’m pretty sure Wilson’s stripper’s name was something sweet.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Maybe his fever is more than the post-op reaction. His girlfriend was sick a few months ago. Maybe her flu was really Epstein-Barr.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Lolly?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: They swap spit, virus travels to his brain, leads to meningitis, leads to increased intracranial pressure.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I agree. Taffy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I agree.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Go ahead. Start him on ribavirin for Epstein-Barr.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keep making decisions like that. It really bolsters the illusion that you’re in charge.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why aren’t you in my office?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because I know what the word “my” means.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I did something insane, and you’re not all over me analyzing why.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It was nice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I gave that idiot an implant to prove to him what an idiot he’s been. How is that nice?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn’t do it to solve the case. You didn’t do it to save his live. You… did it to make his life better. It was a caring act — which you did in a way that was immoral and illegal, but… Baby steps.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Doesn’t sound like us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And you’re okay with that?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What choice do I have?

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Make them take it out.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: They can’t operate again. First you have to get better.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: I don’t want this thing in me.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Seth! Please, God.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: What did you say?

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Seth?

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Is that my name?

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Say it again, please.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Seth. Oh. I think he just wet the bed.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Kid’s dehydrated but stable. Thankfully, the fountain of whiz seems to have stopped for the moment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not before hosing Epstein-Barr off the table. Now eat up. We’re gonna pick out the ice cream flavors for the bachelor party.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Could be systemic autoimmune disease, sarcoido — This tastes like… vodka.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, it would be stupid if it tasted like bourbon. That’s the brown one.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It is vodka?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Flash frozen in a secret process. Guy figured it out in his basement. Limoncello. Genius.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The symptoms came on too hard and too fast. Sarcoidosis is progressive.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Remember in med school when Donovan gave grand rounds? There was that guy who was peeing liters.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Glomerulonephritis? A wrestler. Steroids could have damaged the kidneys. Hmm. The scotch is nice.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His urine would have been brown.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Donovan ruled out osmotic diuresis — kidney disease.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Pheochromocytoma?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No hypertension. Plasma metanephrine’s normal.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Devic’s?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It happened at night. That was the clue. Night, recumbent body position, changes in BP

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s his heart. Run a 12-lead EKG, watch him for four hours. Foreman concurs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What the hell just happened? Everything started to fade away.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You’re getting better at focusing. Ignoring everything that doesn’t matter. Uh-oh. He looks pissed. I think he might hit us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is your eyesight better than mine?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We need to talk about the bachelor party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excellent topic choice. Surgery’s so boring and my lying to you is just so yesterday.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It’s my fault for letting you talk me into the implant. Cameron is not going to be happy about this party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you, on the other hand—

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Plan on spending the rest of my life with Cameron.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So… I need to cancel the fart band?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So… I need you to kidnap me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Spoken like a true Aussie. By the way, if you know where I can get me the sheet music to Waltzing Matilda… Hey. Want some ice cream? We’re having a sundae bar.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Sweet.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: That’s her name.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sundae or bar?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Karamel.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: With a “K.”

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: I wish I could get an implant too.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: You don’t need one. No one does.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: It’s a great thing. It’s going to open up a whole new world for you.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: I don’t want a new world. This doesn’t have to change things.

utterance.speaker: Laura
utterance.content: I’ll be back in a minute. Bathroom?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Down the hall, two doors on your right.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Do I… sound like… her?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It takes time.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You still haven’t slept?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And then I have a clever response.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: EKG normal sinus, normal intervals. His heart’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: His heart’s not fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The heart was fine during this test. The arrhythmia’s hiding.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Or we were wrong about the heart.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Could be the thyroid.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Hashimoto’s would explain the kid’s urine and brain pressure.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Treadmill.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or, the arrhythmia is hiding. We need to stress him. Put the patient on a treadmill.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The patient just had brain surgery. A stress test could cause a brain bleed and kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I value your opinion. I value rejecting your opinion.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re not doing this. You haven’t been sleeping—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cuddy doesn’t actually want you in charge. She just wants to avoid a lawsuit and to win an NAACP award.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And if I let you risk our patient’s life testing an organ we already tested, we accomplish neither. Run a thyroid panel.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do we get him into the stress lab without Foreman’s sign-off.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We could kill Foreman. Is she new?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Focus. The lab simulates stress. What if it’s not simulated?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We could tell him his girlfriend dumped him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s a tough sell since she never leaves the room for more than five minutes.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We could kill her. Or… Asthma meds. Force the heart to beat faster.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Revealing the arrhythmia. Nice idea.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It was yours.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: I just left the room for a few minutes.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He ripped out his implant. So much for improving his life.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Actually, I think we just saved it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Look at that. Arrhythmia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were right about the heart. Should have listened to you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The correct phrasing would be, “I should always listen to you.”

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He’s got problems everywhere. What goes everywhere?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Blood. Could be thrombocythemia. Excess platelets lead to clotting throughout the body.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not with a normal platelet count.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So the clotting doesn’t start in the blood. It starts in the lungs. Pulmonary embolism.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Should do a VQ scan, see if his lungs are clear.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Go.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sure I did this at Wilson’s party?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Last time you used grain alcohol instead of the Sambuca.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And it worked?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: This is why we’re rehearsing. Ever wonder what’s happening every time our patient gets sicker?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not right now!

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: First symptom, wrestling. Then, under the lights of the seizure lab—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you going somewhere with this? Because this feels—

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Just keep doing what you’re doing. It helps. Then, under the stress of blindness… and post-op fever. What do all the symptoms have in common?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Heat. See, if you hadn’t been here that would have just popped into my head. Which actually would have been way cooler. Foreman. The kid’s got Uhthoff Phenomenon. Which means it’s MS. Start him on double-dose interferon.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Let’s get our drink on.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not before I’ve added “chemical burns” to this guy’s cause of death.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Patient’s responding to interferon. Looks like I can retire as department figurehead.

utterance.speaker: Male Officer
utterance.content: Dr. Robert Chase? We’re with the Department of Citizenship and Immigration. Did you recently apply for a marriage license?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Uh… Yes.

utterance.speaker: Male Officer
utterance.content: According to our records, your work permit is expired. If you could come with us.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Um, I’m his fiancé. I can come along and clear this up.

utterance.speaker: Female Officer
utterance.content: I’m sorry, Ma’am. Illegals only.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m… I’m sure it’s a mistake. I’ll call you as soon as I know what’s going on.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don’t let House get him in too much trouble.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Allow me to welcome you to the best night of your life.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: A-huh.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now, ah, a few ground rules for the evening. Uh, safety is job one. We’ve now gone for 18 days without an injury in the workplace. Uh, yes, these girls are all working their way through law school. Don’t test them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew you couldn’t stay away.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This is my apartment. You can’t do this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Clearly, reality begs to differ.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Where’s my furniture?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Out back somewhere.

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: James.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Karamel?

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: Hi. How’s your wife?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Uh… We… We got divorced.

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: Ohhh.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How’s your cat?

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: Dead.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: How ‘bout we go have a drink?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh…

utterance.speaker: Karamel
utterance.content: This way.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re okay with this?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I paid 50 bucks for this.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You guys are great together. Trust is everything. I gotta get some air. Keep it real.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You should be out there, enjoying the lap dances of your labors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Eh. I kinda like it in here.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Me too. To us, figuring out MS.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the blindness and neuropathy and arrhythmia and anything else we did. What exactly did my team do?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Looked good in their lab coats. Except for Taub. Some people just work better alone… so to speak.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: One more drink.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, I can’t. I gotta take a break.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Meet Karamel.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Huh?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Maybe one more drink.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What’s that taste? Is that — Is that strawberry?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, you in there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Use the other bathroom. It’s in the kitchen. Looks like a sink.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Chase went into anaphylactic shock from the stripper’s body butter or something.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is he okay?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: One of the residents had an epi pen, so he’s fine but we’re taking him to the hospital to be safe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. I knew that Chase was allergic to strawberries, didn’t I? That’s why you wanted Karamel at this party.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I suggested Karamel ‘cause she was great at Wilson’s party.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew about her body butter. I knew about his strawberry allergy. I tried to kill Chase. Why would I do that? I don’t want Cameron.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You’re not a big fan of other people’s happiness, either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hello. You confirm? Thanks. That kid we saved… He’s dying. It’s not MS. We were wrong.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Thank God you’re okay. What happened?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Thee was a girl—

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Long story.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Patient’s lung failure rules out MS. We put him on a ventilator.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Uh, enlarged lymphs could—

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Are any of you sober?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Turn around. You need to go to the hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need to sleep.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I’m you. You can’t just shut a door.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You tried to kill Chase. I need to push you back down. You’re dangerous.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It’s the hospital.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not answering. Hello?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m here with your team, trying to sober them up so they can help treat your dying patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Foreman’s dying patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What causes lung failure plus your patient’s previous symptoms?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Eosinophilic pneumonitis. White blood cells accumulate, clog up the lungs, lead to heart problems. It fits.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, are you there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not eosinophilic pneumonitis. I gotta crash.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, don’t hang up. We need your help.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We can solve this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good night.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Eonsinophilic pneumonitis could actually make sense.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No, House ruled it out because it would affect the larynx. Patient would be… hoarse. Which we wouldn’t notice in a deaf kid who rarely speaks.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wait. Everyone’s getting breath mints.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We need to hear Seth speak.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: But that means taking out the tube. Isn’t that dangerous?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’s the safest way to confirm what’s wrong with him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I need him to breathe out as I pull out the tube.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Breathe out.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Say “ah.”

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: Ahhhhhhhhhhhh.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’m sorry. We were wrong. I need to, uh, suction out your throat before we reintubate. Your son smoke?

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Smoke? I don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tobacco stains on his teeth.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: He says he used to chew tobacco to cut weight for wrestling.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Used to.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Chewing tobacco wouldn’t explain his symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But not chewing tobacco might. Taub was right. It’s sarcoidosis. The tobacco releases toxins. Those toxins suppressed his immune system. Once he quit chewing, the absence of those toxins kicked a dormant condition into hyper-drive.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: Is it treatable?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Usually responds to corticosteroids and methotrexate. I’ll start the meds.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need sleeping pills. I was gonna hit up Wilson but he’s not answering his phone.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He must have left it in his pants. Which he wasn’t wearing when the police found him trying to walk home… oddly, from his own apartment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pills.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Your patient’s doing fine, thanks to your team.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It wasn’t eosinophilic pneumonitis, was it?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Sarcoidosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, please talk to me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I haven’t slept through the night since Kutner killed himself.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: The wrestling might have to wait. I’m gonna tell your doctors to repair your implant.

utterance.speaker: Seth
utterance.content: You always said that was my decision.

utterance.speaker: Ellie
utterance.content: And then you ripped it out rather than live with it for a few days even. I’m your mother. This is my call. I don’t know if I’m making the right one, but it’s mine to make.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Sleep well?
